awd_titl_txt: Labor Organization In A Traditional Complex Society
awd_abstract_narration:
Drs. Heather McKillop of Louisiana State University and  E. Cory Sills of The University of Texas at Tyler, along with graduate and undergraduate students will investigate how staple goods and resources are produced and distributed in complex economies, in particular by examining how food staples are produced for marketplace trade. The researchers will examine what factors make small enterprises successful, including the organization and composition of labor and the identification of markets, as well as factors that contribute to failure. Archaeology is particularly useful in addressing these issues due to the material evidence of production, distribution of goods, and the ability to investigate changes over time. The research is important to the United States economy, which includes both large corporations, as well as small businesses, including family-run enterprises. Why do certain factors allow some enterprises to succeed and other's fail? Students, many who are first-generation college students, will be trained in the use of technologies such as Global Positioning Systems, Geographic Information Systems, and 3D digital imaging, all marketable skills in addition to participating in interdisciplinary research in archaeology.  Descendant communities as well as other interested people will be involved in workshops to share findings from the project as well as 3D printed replicas for exhibits. Additionally, the knowledge obtained from this study will be available to interested students, professionals, and the public through an online public repository, web page, and digital updates.  

The researchers will evaluate the production and distribution of salt, a staple good, by study of abandoned salt works where wooden buildings have preserved a record of production untouched from 1500 to 1000 years ago in a coastal lagoon in southern Belize.  As a basic daily necessity, salt was scarce at inland cities so its production on the coast figures into supply and demand of a good distributed at inland marketplaces in cities, towns, and smaller communities. Previous archaeological survey, mapping, and transect excavations indicated massive salt production. However, there were unanswered questions about the workforce, including if they lived near the salt works or elsewhere, if production was organized by households who worked individual salt kitchens or by day or seasonal workers from elsewhere. The researchers will carry out aerial excavations inside multiple buildings and in the adjacent yards at two large archaeological sites to identify residential, production, and other uses. In addition, excavations will be carried out at smaller sites in five different areas of the salt works. Interdisciplinary collaboration includes study of mineralogy of pottery to identify the sources of manufacture as a proxy for the locations of inland markets and consumers. The study incorporates soil chemistry to identify chemical residues of activities, along with quantitative and spatial evaluation of salt production tools. Species identification and radiocarbon dating of wooden posts as well as column samples of the earth beside posts will evaluate the ancient landscape and timing of building construction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Labor Organization in a Traditional Complex Society

Household production and distribution of goods and resources is an important component of many economies, although the degree of state intervention for taxation or control of production varies. How can a reliable supply of essential resources such as salt be maintained? Why do some small family enterprises succeed where others fail? How is labor organized for production and distribution of products? One of these essential resources is salt, a basic biological necessity that is in restricted distribution. Salt can be obtained from mining rock salt, gathered by solar evaporation along coastlines, or evaporated by heating in containers near salt springs or on rainy coastlines. Specialized salt kitchens had been identified at the Paynes Creek Salt Works in Belize, but it was unknown if the workers lived nearby and controlled production, if production was state controlled by inland cities where salt was scarce, or if production was intermittent, as needed, by visitors to the hyper-saline coastal lagoon.

With students and local workers, Heather McKillop of Louisiana State University and E. Cory Sills of the University of Texas at Tyler carried out NSF funded research at the Paynes CreekSalt works. Excavations were carried out at the largest sites in the lagoon where wooden buildings had previously been discovered and mapped forming the walls of buildings preserved below the sea floor. Ten buildings were excavated at Ek Way Nal and Ta’ab Nuk Na, as well as other nearby sites. The associated artifacts were studied to identify building function, resulting in the discovery of both residences and salt kitchens. There was no indication of local overseers of inland state management. Radiocarbon dating each building revealed the rise and expansion of household salt production over 600 years, with related activities such as salting fish, good strategies for risk management in times of fluctuation in demand for salt. Changes in salt production included an increase in efficiency with the use of clay ovens. Ultimately, salt production ended when the demand waned with the abandonment of inland settlements.

Undergraduate and graduate students learned new techniques in shallow underwater archaeology. They participated in interdisciplinary research, both by using techniques from other disciplines and by working with experts in other areas of Anthropology and beyond. Techniques include loss-on ignition (Geology) and using fine mangrove roots in cores for sea-level changes (Mangrove Ecology). Students learned 3D digital imaging to obtain a digital record of the waterlogged finds. They learned 3D printing of the images to create public exhibits featuring 3D printed replicas. I continued to teach courses in 3D digital imaging that I developed from using 3D scanning and printing on previous NSF grants.

 Results were shared at professional conferences, in journal publications, on the project web page, and in social media. Exhibits in display cabinets featuring 3D printed replicas of finds, along with laminated posters and signs are aimed at reaching a general public audience in the nearest communities to the fieldwork. The exhibits feature public openings with public talks, including schools. The focus of exhibits was the Toledo Info Center in Punta Gorda where Maya from outlying villages come to market and can access the displays.
